skill.name: Metabolomics Workbench Database
skill.description: Access NIH Metabolomics Workbench via REST API (4,200+ studies). Query metabolites, RefMet nomenclature, MS/NMR data, m/z searches, study metadata, for metabolomics and biomarker discovery.
skill.summary: Access NIH Metabolomics Workbench REST API for metabolomics data, metabolite structures, and study metadata
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing markdown files with example API usage. Static analyzer flagged example code snippets and markdown formatting as security patterns. No executable code exists. All findings are false positives.

static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Markdown code block delimiter (triple backticks) in documentation, not Ruby backtick command execution. No executable code exists in skill.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] external_commands: Ruby/shell backtick execution at references/api_reference.md:6

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [LOW] network: Python HTTP libraries at SKILL.md:36
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Example requests.get() call in documentation showing how to use NIH Metabolomics Workbench API. Documentation only, no network calls executed.
Legitimate NIH API endpoint (metabolomicsworkbench.org) documented for reference. This is proper documentation of public API.

static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Static analyzer misinterpreting YAML front matter or documentation formatting as cryptographic patterns. No cryptographic code exists.

static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Documentation example showing how to save downloaded structure file. Example code only, no file operations executed.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [CRITICAL] sensitive: Windows SAM database at references/api_reference.md:221
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Static analyzer misinterpreting 'SAM' abbreviation in MetStat context table (Sample source/Analytical Method parameters). No Windows files or credential databases accessed.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [CRITICAL] obfuscation: [HEURISTIC] DANGEROUS COMBINATION: Code execution + Network + Credential access
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Documentation showing API usage patterns does not constitute obfuscation or credential access. No credentials are involved with NIH public API.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [HIGH] blocker: Weak cryptographic algorithm at references/api_reference.md:34
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Static analyzer misinterpreting table formatting (pipes |) in markdown tables as cryptographic patterns. No weak crypto code exists.
Documentation describes output format specifications (JSON vs TXT), not system reconnaissance. No scanning or reconnaissance code exists.

content.value_statement: Search and retrieve metabolomics data from the NIH Metabolomics Workbench database containing 4,200+ studies. Access metabolite structures, study metadata, RefMet nomenclature, and perform mass spectrometry searches.
actual_capabilities: Query metabolite structures by PubChem CID, InChI Key, HMDB ID, KEGG ID
Search metabolomics studies by metabolite, disease, species, and analytical method
Standardize metabolite names using RefMet classification hierarchy
Perform mass spectrometry m/z searches with ion adduct support
Access gene and protein information from MGP database
Download molecular structures as MOL or PNG files
limitations: Does not provide wet-lab experimental protocols
No metabolite pathway analysis or visualization tools
Cannot perform statistical analysis on study data
API rate limits apply for high-volume queries

use_cases.title: Find studies for a metabolite
use_cases.description: Search all metabolomics studies containing measurements of a specific metabolite like glucose or citrate.

use_cases.title: Identify compounds from MS data
use_cases.description: Input m/z values from mass spectrometry to identify potential metabolite candidates matching your data.

use_cases.title: Filter studies by disease
use_cases.description: Find metabolomics studies for specific diseases like diabetes or cancer using specific analytical platforms.

prompt_templates.title: Find metabolite studies
prompt_templates.prompt: Find all studies in the Metabolomics Workbench that contain measurements of [metabolite_name]. Return study IDs and brief descriptions.

prompt_templates.title: Identify compound from m/z
prompt_templates.prompt: Search the Metabolomics Workbench for compounds matching m/z [value] with [M+H] adduct and 0.5 Da tolerance. List the top matches.

prompt_templates.title: Standardize metabolite name
prompt_templates.prompt: Use RefMet to standardize the metabolite name [common_name]. Return the standardized name and classification hierarchy.

prompt_templates.title: Filter by disease and platform
prompt_templates.prompt: Find human blood metabolomics studies on [disease_name] using [LCMS or GCMS or NMR] analytical method.

output: â€¢ ST000001 - Comprehensive metabolomics analysis of amino acid metabolism
â€¢ ST000015 - Tyrosine metabolic pathways in liver tissue
â€¢ ST000042 - Serum amino acid profiling in metabolic disorders
Study summary: The Metabolomics Workbench contains 47 studies measuring tyrosine across various tissues, species, and disease states.

best_practices: Use RefMet to standardize metabolite names before searching studies for consistent results
Set appropriate mass tolerance based on your instrument resolution (0.5 Da for low-res, 0.01 Da for high-res MS)
Cache RefMet database locally when making many queries to reduce API calls
anti_patterns: Searching for metabolites without using RefMet standardization may miss relevant studies
Using excessive mass tolerance returns too many false positive matches
Making rapid sequential requests without delays may trigger rate limiting

faq.question: What is the Metabolomics Workbench?
faq.answer: NIH Common Fund-sponsored repository at UCSD hosting 4,200+ metabolomics studies with standardized data.

faq.question: What is RefMet?
faq.answer: Standardized metabolite nomenclature database with hierarchical classification from broad class to specific compound.

faq.question: What ion adducts should I use?
faq.answer: M+H for positive mode ESI, M-H for negative mode ESI. Use M+Na if sodium adducts are common in your samples.

faq.question: How do I download metabolite structures?
faq.answer: Use the compound context with PNG output format to download structure images, or MOL for molecular format files.

faq.question: What study parameters can I filter by?
faq.answer: Filter by analysis type, polarity, chromatography, species, sample source, disease, and specific metabolites via MetStat.

faq.question: Does this skill require API authentication?
faq.answer: No, the NIH Metabolomics Workbench REST API is freely accessible without authentication for public data.
